Enclcyopedia of African American Culture and History

Name/Location Notes: a community in the southern planning area of Goodyear, Maricopa County,

Other Unique History: The community was named after Epes Randolph, a vice-president and general manager of the Southern Pacific Railroad, who founded the town in the early 1920s. Randolph wanted to establish a successful city near Casa Grande. On July 18, 1925, the Randolph Post Office opened, with Channing E. Babbitt as its postmaster. With the increased need for agricultural workers which arose in the late 1920s, hundreds of farm workers migrated to the area in the 1930s. Many of those who settled in Randolph were black migrants from Oklahoma. This influx created a community which was predominantly black. The post office closed in 1983.
One of the oldest all black incorpotated towns in US

Other_notes: Area of Topeka bounded by S.W. Clay, S.W. Washburn, Huntoon and 10th

Founder(s) Name(s): Francis “Frank” Marion Boyer and his wife Ella Louise
Other unique history source?: Deprived from the previous freedman colony, Blackdom
